conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same velocity at time t1, we need to analyze the given acceleration-time graph.

The graph shows the relationship between acceleration (a) and time (t). Object A has a constant acceleration a_A from t = 0 to t = t_2. Object B has a constant acceleration a_B from t = 0 to t = t_1, and then it stops accelerating (i.e., a_B = 0 for t > t_1).
The velocity of an object is the integral of its acceleration with respect to time.
For object A, the acceleration is constant a_A from t = 0 to t = t_1. The velocity of object A at t_1 is v_A(t_1) = a_A * t_1.
For object B, the acceleration is constant a_B from t = 0 to t = t_1. The velocity of object B at t_1 is v_B(t_1) = a_B * t_1.

At time t_1, the velocity of object A is v_A(t_1) = a_A * t_1. At time t_1, the velocity of object B is v_B(t_1) = a_B * t_1. For the velocities to be the same at t_1, we need a_A * t_1 = a_B * t_1, which implies a_A = a_B.
If a_A = a_B, then the velocities of objects A and B at t_1 are the same. If a_A â‰  a_B, then the velocities of objects A and B at t_1 are different.
Since the problem does not specify the values of a_A and a_B, we cannot definitively say whether the velocities are the same without additional information.
Based on the given information, the velocities will be the same at t_1 if and only if a_A = a_B.
At time t_1, the two objects have the same velocity if and only if their accelerations a_A and a_B are equal.
